Course Description: This course delves into advanced computer architecture, focusing on the design and optimization of high-performance computing systems. It covers instruction-level and data-level parallelism, including superscalar processors, GPUs, and vector architectures. The curriculum explores sophisticated memory hierarchy designs, emerging memory technologies, and domain-specific accelerators like TPUs. Furthermore, students will examine the application of AI/ML techniques for architectural enhancements, such as cache optimization and power management. A critical component addresses security vulnerabilities, including side-channel attacks. Upon completion, students can analyze complex architectures, identify performance bottlenecks, and propose effective mitigation strategies, encompassing security considerations.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Instruction Level Parallelism and Superscalar Processors; Microarchitecture design and analysis of Out-of-Order processors; Compiler and Architecture Interactions.
Unit 2: Data Level Parallelism and SIMD/GPU Architectures; Vector Architectures; GPUs; Compiler and Architecture Interactions.
Unit 3: Memory Hierarchy Design and Emerging Memory Technologies; Design of Cache Memory; Distributed Shared Memory; Memory Consistency Models; Non-volatile memories.
Unit 4: Emerging and Domain Specific Accelerators; Hardware accelerators for deep neural networks and Genomics; AMD AI/ML Engine; TPUs.
Unit 5: AI/ML Techniques in Architecture; Reinforcement Learning Techniques in Cache Optimization, Branch Prediction etc.; Power Management.
Unit 6: Security; Side Channel Attacks such as Spectre and Meltdown

Course Description: This course offers a rigorous examination of the philosophical foundations and analytical tools necessary for critical ethical inquiry. It navigates foundational concepts, argument analysis, and delves into challenges such as moral skepticism, cultural relativism, and the nature of 'good'. The curriculum then explores moral responsibility and critically evaluates major normative theories—consequentialism, deontology, and virtue ethics—applying them to contemporary ethical dilemmas. Students will develop advanced skills in analyzing ethical arguments, formulating nuanced justifications, and applying diverse normative frameworks to complex moral problems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit I- Introduction: Distinction between conventional and critical ethics, philosophical tools for argument analysis, intuition, evidence, justification, and explanation.

Unit II - Skepticism: Intrinsic vs Instrumental value, challenge of egoism, problem of cultural relativity and subjectivism, error theory and nihilism, distinction between being ethical and seeming ethical.
Unit III - Goodness: the problem of defining 'good', naturalistic fallacy and the open question argument, implications of the experience machine thought experiment.
Unit IV - Responsibility: challenge of attributing moral responsibility to agents, the control, competence and epistemic conditions of responsibility, moral luck.
Unit V - Normative theories: Consequentialism, deontology, and virtue ethics.
Unit VI - Practical ethics: discussion of specific moral problems

Course Description: Automata Theory provides a foundational exploration into theoretical computation, examining abstract machines and the formal languages they process. The course systematically covers finite automata (DFA, NFA) and their relationship with regular languages, including expressions and grammars. It then progresses to context-free grammars and pushdown automata, analyzing context-free languages. Finally, it introduces Turing machines, exploring universal computation, recursive languages, and fundamental concepts of computability and its inherent limitations. Students will gain proficiency in designing computational models, classifying formal languages, and understanding computational theory's boundaries.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction, Finite State Machines, Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA), Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFA), Equivalence of NFA and DFA, Regular Expressions, Regular Languages, Closure Properties of regular languages, Pumping Lemma, Grammars, Left and Right-linear grammars.

Unit 2: Context Free Grammar (CFG), Chomsky Normal Form, Push Down Automata (PDA), Equivalence of CFG and PDA, Context Free Languages (CFL), Deterministic PDA and Deterministic CFL, Pumping Lemma for context free languages.
Unit 3: Introduction to Turing machines, Total Turing Machines, Recursive languages, Recursively enumerable languages, The Halting problem

CO4: Students will evaluate the computability of a language using Turing machines with recursive languages meeting industry standards

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive foundation in behavioral research, focusing on experimental design principles and methodologies. It covers the entire research process, from hypothesis formulation, operationalization, and literature review to various experimental designs, data collection strategies (including web/mobile and crowdsourcing), and advanced statistical analysis techniques like descriptive, inferential, and data reduction methods. Students will develop the practical skills to design, deploy, and analyze behavioral experiments, critically evaluate ethical considerations, and effectively communicate their research findings in academic formats.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Introduction to Research Methods: Qualitative and Quantitative Approaches; Conducting Behavioural Research; Ethics in Research; Institute Review Board (IRB) Process.

2. Starting on Research, Experimental Design: Hypothesis Testing, Type I and II errors, Hypothesis-based vs Exploratory Research, Operationalizing Research, Literature Review; Sampling, Types of variables and levels of Measurements, Designing an Experiment; Validity, Reliability and Cross-validation in Research.

3. Types of Experimental design: Non-Experimental Designs, Pilot Testing; Data Collection: Surveys Questionnaires; Data Representation: Levels of Measurement, Human Annotation, Different types of design: Simple randomized design, Factorial designs, Simple repeated measures design, Randomized blocks design, Latin square type designs, Between-subject and within-subject factors in an experiment; Scaling Behavioural Experiments: web and mobile experiments, crowdsourcing, big data, large-scale experiments, citizen science, online data collection (PsiTurk, Mechanical Turk, etc).

4. Data Visualization and Analysis: Descriptive Statistics, Tests of Normality and Data Transformation, Outliers, Collinearity in Data, Data Summarization vs Data Reduction Techniques: Exploratory Factor Analysis, Principal Component Analysis, Discriminant Factor Analysis.

5. Introduction to Statistical Analysis: Inferential Statistics-Tests of Difference and Tests of Association: Multi-level tests (ANOVA): nonparametric and parametric tests of difference chi-square test, Mann Whitney U test, Binomial Sign test, Wilcoxon's T test, Related and Unrelated t tests; nonparametric and parametric tests of association correlation, regression; Significance testing.
6. Communicating and Assessing Research: Writing, Poster and general Presentations (formatting of the research paper using APA and IEEE journal/conference formats)

CO4: Students will apply inferential statistical methods to test hypotheses with a significance level of 0.05

Course Description: This course delves into the fundamental principles and design of bio-instrumentation and devices, with a primary focus on electrophysiological signal acquisition and processing. It covers the generation of biological signals, their capture using micro-electrode systems, and subsequent amplification and conditioning via instrumentation amplifiers and specialized low-power CMOS circuits. The curriculum further explores Bio-MEMs, microfluidics, and lab-on-a-chip diagnostic devices, alongside various semiconductor and non-electrical sensing technologies. Students will gain the ability to design and analyze systems for processing electrophysiological signals and understand the operation of cutting-edge diagnostic tools.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Biological signals: electrophysiology (cardio, near, muscular); other signals. Understanding various biological system and the electrical signal they generate. Capturing the signals for biomedical systems. Micro-electrode arrays and micro-electrode systems.
Module 2: Amplification & Signal Conditioning basics: Opamps; Instrumentation Amplifier; TIA: Review of analog circuits and amplifiers (AEC). Circuit system for specific applications.
Module 3: CMOS VLSI circuit design, Potentiostat; switch cap amps: Discussion and analysis of specialized circuits and circuit design techniques for low power.

Module 4: Diagnostic devices: UTAS & Lab-on-a-chip (RT PCR, On-chip-olfaction): Introduction to Bio-MEMs, Micro-fluidics. Basics of device fabrication theory (non-semiconductor). Status quo and review of some cutting-edge lab-on-chip applications. Introduction to smart systems.

Module 5: JFET, ISFET, ChemFET; Non-electrical devices: Introduction to other semiconductor and non-semiconductor-based devices. Discussion and working of various devices. Current and future trends. Brief discussion on FinFETs.
Module 6: Noise & noise efficient design

Course Description: This course explores chemical kinetics and reaction dynamics, foundational to understanding chemical change. It covers empirical rate laws, integrated kinetics, and temperature dependence, progressing to complex reaction mechanisms, homogeneous catalysis, and photochemistry. Students will delve into molecular reaction dynamics, applying collision and transition state theories to interpret potential energy surfaces. The curriculum also examines electron transfer processes and modern ultrafast laser techniques. Ultimately, students will analyze reaction mechanisms, predict rates, and connect theoretical principles to experimental observations and practical applications across scientific and industrial fields.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Empirical chemical kinetics: Experimental techniques; The rates of reactions; Integrated rate laws; Reactions approaching equilibrium; The temperature dependence of reaction rates; Accounting for the rate laws; Elementary reactions; Consecutive elementary reactions; Impact on biochemistry: The kinetics of the helix-coil transition in polypeptides; Unimolecular reactions. (2L)

Unit 2: Chain reactions; The rate laws of chain reactions; Explosions; Polymerization kinetics; Stepwise polymerization; Chain polymerization; Homogeneous catalysis; Features of homogeneous catalysis; Enzymes. (2L)

Unit 3: Photochemistry, Kinetics of photophysical and photochemical processes; Impact on: The chemistry of stratospheric ozone; Applications: Impact on environmental sciences, biochemistry, and other areas. (1L)
Unit 4: Molecular Reaction Dynamics: Reactive encounters; Collision theory; Diffusion-controlled reactions; The material balance equation. (2L)

Unit 5: Transition state theory; The Eyring equation; Thermodynamic aspects; The dynamics of molecular collisions; Reactive collisions; Potential energy surfaces; Some results from experiments and calculations. (2L)

Unit 6: The investigation of reaction dynamics with ultrafast laser techniques; Electron transfer in homogeneous systems; The rates of electron transfer processes; Theory of electron transfer processes; Experimental results; Impact on biochemistry: Electron transfer in and between proteins. (2L)
Unit 7: Special topics (oscillating reactions, etc.)

Course Description: Computational Linguistics 2 delves into advanced aspects of natural language understanding, focusing on semantic and pragmatic analysis. The course comprehensively explores word and sentence meaning, including lexical relations, ambiguity, and formal semantic representations. A significant emphasis is placed on computational pragmatics and discourse analysis, covering context-dependent meaning, conversational structure, coherence, and speaker intention. Topics further extend to knowledge representation, text classification, sentiment analysis, Gricean maxims, and speech act theory. Students will acquire the skills to develop computational resources for contextual text interpretation and apply cutting-edge CL/NLP techniques to real-world dialogue and discourse data, enabling both theoretical research and practical application.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Background for studying word meaning and sentence meaning, sentence meaning and propositional content; sense and reference; referent, extension, prototype, stereotype; deixis and definiteness; predicates, referring expressions, universe of discourse; properties of sentences analytic, contradiction, entailment; properties of predicates - reflexive, symmetry, transitive. Word meaning and sentence meaning, content word and grammatical word, contextual variation; Speaker meaning vs Sentence meaning. Building resources using Lexical semantic relations Synonymy, Antonymy, Hyponymy, Troponymy, Meronymy; Metaphor and Metonymy; Polysemy and Homonymy; Semantic fields; Lexical ambiguity; Building dictionaries; Ontologies.

Unit 2: Formal Semantics: Formal representation of natural language semantic features, case frames, semantic primitives. Logic, notation for simple propositions; connectives and, or, but, if etc.; Logical expressions for ambiguous sentences.

Unit 3: Pragmatics and Discourse: Pragmatics and Discourse analysis as a study of context dependent aspects of meaning; text, co-text, context and relevance. Computational Discourse analysis: Studying Structure of text and coherence; exchange structure and conversational analysis; turn taking; adjacency pairs; preference organization; deixis; anaphora; ellipsis; discourse connectives and relations; Structural analysis of different kinds of texts.

Unit 4: Text classification and generation: Memory and knowledge representation as schemas - frames, scripts and story grammar; Generation and processing of texts: Sentiment Analysis. Humour Analysis.

Unit 5: Computational Pragmatics: Language Understanding; Meaning beyond textual context; speaker's intention and hearer's inference; inference bridging inferences, causal and spatial inferences, elaborative and restrictive inferences; Application of pragmatic concepts in Dialogue Systems: conversational implicature, conventional implicature, entailment and presupposition; co-operative interaction and Gricean maxims; speech act theory; language as action, performatives, direct and indirect speech acts and felicity conditions; politeness maxims; Austin and Searle's speech acts; Dialogue data annotation: Dialog Acts, Rhetorical Structure Theory

CO3: Students will evaluate the role of speaker intention and hearer's inference in computational pragmatics using Gricean maxims and speech act theory with clear justifications
CO4: Students will design and implement a text classification system using machine learning algorithms and sentiment analysis with 90% precision

Course Description: This course explores the essential principles and practices of Design for Testability (DFT) in VLSI circuit design. This equips students to address semiconductor circuit testing issues early, thereby reducing production costs and improving product yield.

Course Description: This course introduces fundamental concepts in discrete mathematics, essential for computer science. Course Title: Earthquake Resistant Design of Masonry Structures
Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles of earthquake-resistant design for masonry structures, addressing their inherent seismic vulnerability. It meticulously examines the material properties and complex behavior of masonry under various actions, including compression, tension, shear, and bending, especially under seismic loading. Students will analyze common failure modes observed in past earthquakes and understand codal provisions for seismic safety. The curriculum covers the design of strengthening components and delves into advanced techniques for assessing the seismic safety of existing masonry buildings, equipping students to recommend and implement effective retrofit measures.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction to masonry, Masonry buildings in India, Material properties, Masonry units, Manufacturing process, Mortar, Grout, and reinforcement; Masonry assemblages, Masonry systems, Various tests, and standards.

Unit 2: Masonry under compression: Prism strength, Failure mechanism, types of construction and bonds, Eccentric loading, Slenderness effective length and effective height, effect of openings, Code provisions, masonry in tension, flexural strength of masonry, shear and bending capacity of masonry.

Unit 3: Behavior of masonry structures during past earthquakes: Common modes of failures, effect of roof and floor systems, Masonry under lateral loads: In-plane and out-of-plane loads, bending parallel and perpendicular to bed joints, Shear and flexure behavior of piers, Test and standards, lateral force distribution for flexible and rigid diaphragms, Combined axial and bending actions.

Unit 4: Earthquake Resistant Measures: Analysis for earthquake forces, role of floor and roof diaphragm, Pier analysis using equivalent stiffness approach, Concept and design of bands, splints and bandages, Vertical reinforcement at corners and jambs, Code provisions.
Unit 5: Retrofitting of masonry building: Techniques of repair and retrofitting of masonry buildings, IS: 13935 provisions for retrofitting, different strengthening methodologies and techniques

CO2: Students will design a masonry structure to resist earthquake forces, given a dataset of seismic loads and site conditions, meeting industry standards for seismic safety.

CO3: Students will evaluate the effectiveness of strengthening components and retrofitting techniques for existing masonry buildings, using IS: 13935 provisions and relevant case studies, with 90% accuracy.
CO4: Students will develop a detailed design for a masonry pier, considering in-plane and out-of-plane loads, and axial and bending actions, using equivalent stiffness approach with 85% accuracy.

CO5: Students will implement a seismic retrofitting plan for a masonry building, incorporating bands, splints, and bandages, and vertical reinforcement at corners and jambs, meeting code provisions for seismic safety.

CO6: Students will create a report detailing the common modes of failure observed in past earthquakes, and the role of roof and floor systems, using relevant literature and case studies, with 80% accuracy.

Course Description: This course delves into the foundational principles of Information Theory, exploring concepts such as entropy, mutual information, and their role in quantifying uncertainty. It systematically examines stochastic processes, including Markov chains and random walks, and applies these principles to critical areas like data compression and channel capacity. The curriculum covers the construction of optimal codes and the determination of channel limits. Furthermore, students will synthesize proofs of fundamental theorems and investigate advanced topics like differential entropy and maximum entropy. The course culminates in the ability to analyze communication systems and design robust communication models, preparing students for practical applications in communication theory.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. ENTROPY CONCEPT IN PROBABILITY THEORY: Entropy of Finite Schemes, Joint Entropy and Conditional Entropy, Relative Entropy and Mutual Information, Chain Rules, The Uniqueness Theorem, Jensen's Inequality, Log Sum Inequality, Data Processing Inequalities, Sufficient Statistics, Fano's Inequality.
2. PROBABILITY MEASURE AND ASYMPTOTIC EQUIPARTION PROPERTY: Probability as a measure, Law of Large Number, Asymptotic Equipartition Theorem (AEP), Data Compression, Typical Sets.
3. ENTROPY RATES OF A STOCHASTIC PROCESS: Entropy of Markov Chains, Entropy Rate, Entropy Rate of a random walk on a weighted graph, Hidden Markov Models, Fundamental Theorems.
4. DATA COMPRESSION: Kraft Inequality, Optimal Codes, Bound on the optimal code length, Kraft inequality for Uniquely Decodable Codes, Huffman Codes, Optimality of Huffman code.

5. CHANNEL CAPACITY: Examples of Channel Capacity, Symmetric Channels, Properties of Channel Capacity, Joint Typical Sequence, Channel Coding theorem, Zero Error Codes, Fano's Inequality, Feedback Capacity.

6. DIFFERENTIAL ENTROPY MAXIMUM ENTROPY AND SPECTRAL ESTIMATION: Definition, AEP for Continuous Random Variable, Relation of Differential Entropy to Discrete Entropy, Joint and Conditional Entropy, Relative Entropy and Mutual Information, Maximum Entropy distributions, Anomalous Maximum Entropy Problem, Spectrum Estimation
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will calculate entropy and mutual information of discrete random variables given probability distributions with 90% accuracy
CO2: Students will develop optimal codes using Huffman coding and Kraft inequality in a data compression scenario
CO3: Students will analyze channel capacity and construct optimal channel codes using joint typical sequences in a noisy channel environment
CO4: Students will apply the asymptotic equipartition property to stochastic processes and evaluate the entropy rate of Markov chains and random walks
CO5: Students will design and evaluate robust communication models using differential entropy and maximum entropy principles in a real-world communication system
CO6: Students will prove fundamental theorems in information theory, including the uniqueness theorem and Fano's inequality, and justify their applications
CO7: Students will synthesize and compare different data compression techniques, including Huffman codes and uniquely decodable codes, and evaluate their efficiency in a given dataset

Course Title: Fairness, Privacy and Ethics in Al
Course Description: This course critically examines fairness, privacy, and ethical considerations in AI systems. Students will investigate sources of algorithmic bias, exploring diverse notions of individual fairness (e.g., envy-freeness) and group fairness (e.g., equalized odds). The curriculum synthesizes algorithms to mitigate discrimination, addressing the complexities of achieving equitable AI. Additionally, it tackles data privacy challenges, covering potential attacks on machine learning models. Practical techniques like differential privacy (e.g., Laplace, Gaussian mechanisms) are applied to ensure robust individual privacy, fostering transparency and responsible AI development.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Bias in the data, causality, Individual fairness vs group fairness.
Unit 2: Individual fairness: envy freeness, max-min share, proportionality. Algorithms to achieve them such as round robin, cycle elimination, etc.
Unit 3: Impossibility of fair classifier with perfect calibration.

Unit 4: Group fairness (equalized odds, disparate impact, accuracy parity, predictive parity). Different preprocessing, post processing techniques and over all approach to build Al to mitigate discrimination.
Unit 5: Differential Privacy (DP), Need for newer privacy measures, especially when federated learning is on rise. Possible attacks even data is anonymized.
Unit 6: Techniques such as Laplace mechanism, gaussian mechanism, local DP, Bayesian DP
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will identify sources of algorithmic bias in AI systems given a dataset with 85% accuracy
CO2: Students will design algorithms to achieve individual fairness, such as envy-freeness and proportionality, using Python with 90% efficiency
CO3: Students will analyze the impossibility of fair classifiers with perfect calibration in a theoretical context with supporting mathematical proofs
CO4: Students will develop strategies to mitigate discrimination in AI systems using preprocessing and post-processing techniques, meeting industry standards for fairness
CO5: Students will apply differential privacy mechanisms, such as Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms, to ensure robust individual privacy in a federated learning setting with 95% confidence
CO6: Students will evaluate the effectiveness of various fairness and privacy techniques in real-world AI applications, considering multiple stakeholders' perspectives
CO7: Students will create a responsible AI development plan, incorporating fairness, privacy, and ethical considerations, in a collaborative group project with a clear project timeline

Course Description: This course offers a foundational understanding of the Finite Element Method (FEM), beginning with core principles and approximate solution techniques for boundary value problems. It systematically covers the formulation and application of FEM to one-dimensional scenarios, including structural elements like bars, beams, and trusses. The curriculum advances to two-dimensional problems, exploring triangular, quadrilateral, and isoparametric elements, coupled with essential numerical integration methods. Students will gain proficiency in formulating, solving, and analyzing complex structural and elasticity problems using finite element techniques.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to finite element method (FEM): Need for FEM, General finite element solution procedure, Boundary value problems: types of boundary conditions, Approximate solution to boundary value problems: Method of weighted residuals.

Module 2: General one-dimensional (1D) boundary value problem and its applications: Axial deformation of bars: Approximate solution using Rayleigh-Ritz method, Galerkin method, Axial Spring element. Applications: One-dimensional heat flow, Column buckling. Higher order elements for 1D problems.

Module 3: Beams, Frames and Trusses: Beam bending-governing differential equation, Two node beam element, Analysis of structural frames-Plane frame element, space frame element, Introduction to truss analysis.

Module 4: 2D boundary value problems: triangular elements, isoparametric quadrilateral elements, Isoparametric mapping for quadrilateral elements, Numerical integration for quadrilateral elements, Four node quadrilateral element for 2D BVP, Eight node serendipity element. Isoparametric triangular elements.

Module 5: Applications based on general 2D boundary value problem: Torsion of prismatic bars. 2D elasticity-Governing differential equations, Constant strain triangular element, Four node quadrilateral element, Eight node isoparametric element. Constitutive equations, governing differential equations, stress equilibrium equations, finite element equations for plane stress and plane strain conditions.

Module 6: Numerical integration-Newton-Cotes rules, Trapezium rule, Simpson's rule, Error term, Gauss-Legendre rules, Gauss-Leguerre rule, Numerical integration for quadrilateral elements, Numerical integration for triangular elements
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will formulate and solve one-dimensional boundary value problems using the finite element method with 80% accuracy
CO2: Students will develop and analyze structural elements, including bars, beams, and trusses, using finite element techniques in a lab setting
CO3: Students will apply the Galerkin method to approximate solutions of boundary value problems with a minimum of 90% convergence
CO4: Students will design and implement two-dimensional finite element models using triangular and quadrilateral elements with efficient numerical integration
CO5: Students will evaluate the performance of finite element solutions for plane stress and plane strain conditions, meeting industry standards for accuracy
CO6: Students will construct and analyze isoparametric elements for two-dimensional boundary value problems using numerical integration methods with a maximum error of 5%

Course Title: Foundations for Signal Processing and Communication
Course Description: This course establishes a rigorous mathematical foundation for understanding and designing signal processing and communication systems. It systematically explores probability theory, random variables, and stochastic processes, applying these to analyze communication channels and noise. Further, it delves into abstract algebra and linear algebra, covering vector spaces, linear transformations, Fourier analysis, and their applications in signal representation and system analysis. Students will develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills, enabling them to apply these mathematical tools to complex problems and conduct foundational research in communication and signal processing.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Rigorous Math Part: Probability Axioms, Random Variables and their distributions (CDF, PDF, PMF), Some Important Distributions, Joint and Conditional Distributions, Distributions of functions of Random Variables, Expectation of RVs and their functions; SPCOM Part: Random quantities in SPCOM, Notion of Communication Channel, Hypothesis testing, Simple Detection and Estimation problems in Signal Engineering.

Module 2: Rigorous Math Part: Concentration inequalities (Markov, Chebyshev, Chernoff), Central Limit Theorem, Mean vector and covariance matrix, Joint Gaussian Distribution, Random Processes; SPCOM Part: Discrete Memoryless Channels and Notion of Channel Capacity, Gaussian Noise, Wireless Channel.

Module 3: Sets with structure; Rigorous Math Part: Groups, Rings, Fields, Vector spaces, Inner Product on Vector Spaces; SPCOM part: The Vector Space of Finite Energy Continuous Signals, Vector Space of Sampled Signals, Vector Space of discrete-time quantized signals, Distinguishing features of Digital Signal Processing and Communication.

Module 4: Rigorous Math part: Linear Independence/dependence, Span, Column space and row space of matrices, Basis and Dimension of subspaces, Basis Extension Theorem, Rank of a matrix, Change of Basis; SPCOM part: Fourier Series of L_2 signals as representation of signals using Fourier basis, Finite dimensionality of bounded-time, bounded-bandwidth L_2 signals, standard basis for Discrete-time signals, Standard Basis for Finite-field Signals, Discrete Fourier Transform as Change of Basis.

Module 5: Rigorous Math Part: Linear Transformations between vector spaces and their associated Matrices, Eigen Values and Vectors, Triangularization, Diagonalization, SVD; SPCOM part: Continuous-time and Discrete-Time LTI systems and their Transfer Functions, Role of linear transformations in coding theory for forward-error correction, Do Estimation, MIMO Wireless Communication
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will apply probability theory and stochastic processes to analyze communication channels and noise with 85% accuracy
CO2: Students will develop and implement hypothesis testing and detection problems in signal engineering using Python with a minimum of 90% detection rate
CO3: Students will construct and analyze vector spaces, linear transformations, and Fourier analysis to represent signals and systems with precise mathematical derivations
CO4: Students will design and evaluate communication systems using abstract algebra and linear algebra techniques with 80% system efficiency
CO5: Students will create and apply signal processing algorithms using linear transformations, eigenvalues, and SVD to real-world communication scenarios with a minimum of 95% signal fidelity
CO6: Students will analyze and compare different communication channels and systems using probability theory, random processes, and information theory with 90% accuracy
CO7: Students will develop and conduct foundational research in communication and signal processing using mathematical tools and techniques with publishable quality

Course Title: Introduction to Neural and Cognitive Modeling
Course Description: This course introduces the foundational principles and applications of neural and cognitive modeling, exploring how mathematical and computational methods illuminate brain function. Participants will learn C programming for Arduino and ESP32 platforms, exploring hardware interfacing, communication protocols, and advanced peripherals. The curriculum extends to IoT networking, cloud computing, data analysis, interoperability standards, and security considerations. Upon completion, learners will be equipped to design, develop, and implement robust IoT-based solutions for complex real-world problems, from conceptualization to visualization.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Basic properties of electricity and electrical circuits - DC, Voltage, Current, Power, Energy, Resistance, Ohm’s Law, Circuit Diagrams.
2. Kirchoff’s voltage and current laws, series and parallel resistance, Voltage and Current divider.
3. Online Simulations using TinkerCAD.
4. Basic Circuits, Mesh analysis, Node analysis.
5. What is IoT, Embedded Systems, Components of Embedded Systems, Microcontrollers, Sensors and Actuators, Analog/Digital conversion, Internet structure, Protocols, TCP/IP.
6. Arduino Environment, C Programming, Arduino programming and debugging, URAT Protocol.
7. Interfacing with Arduino, Pulse Width Modulation, Arduino Libraries, I2C communication, Arduino Shields.
8. Peripherals: RTC, ADC channels, resolution, onboard memory, power, external/internal watchdog.
9. Communications and Networking in IoT.
10. Cloud Computing and Data Analysis.
11. Interoperability Standards and security.
12. Dashboard and Visualization.
13. Documentation and Productization

Course Description: This course explores the intricate relationship between language and society, focusing on core principles of sociolinguistics. Students will investigate phenomena such as language variation, dialects, and contact situations like bilingualism and code-switching. The curriculum delves into social stratification of language, cultural influences, and critical perspectives on language and power dynamics. Practical applications include analyzing language data using learned concepts, interpreting findings for computational models, and developing real-world solutions. Through team-based projects, students will gain confidence in designing and implementing computational models in authentic social contexts.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Language Variation: Sociolinguistics and sociology of language, Variation in language, Linguistic variables and social variables. Speech Communities, Language, Dialects and Varieties. Standard language and Standardization, Regional and social dialects. Register, styles. Dialectology.

2. Language Contact: Bilingualism/Multilingualism, borrowing, code mixing/switching, pidginization and creolization, convergence, language maintenance/shift, language acquisition in a multilingual setting. Diglossia with or without bilingualism.

3. Social stratification of language. Inherent variability. Sociolinguistic variables: indicator, marker, stereotype. Style shifting. Hypercorrection. Language variation and language change. Social motivation for sound change. Sociolinguistic devices for effective communication. Communicative competence. Politeness strategies. Pronouns of power and solidarity.
4. Language and Culture: Directions of influence. The Whorfian hypothesis.
5. Critical Sociolinguistics. Language and power. Language and social attitudes: gender, race, education.
6. Language planning: codification and elaboration

Course Description: Modern Coding Theory explores the theoretical foundations and practical applications of error-correcting codes for reliable data transmission. 5. Recursive Constructions for Berman Codes and Polar Codes: Definitions, basic properties, idea of capacity achieving nature in BMS channels

Course Description: This course delves into Modern Complexity Theory, exploring fundamental models of computation, including Turing Machines and Boolean Circuits, alongside inherent impossibility results. A central focus will be on designing reductions to demonstrate problem hardness and completeness for various classes. The curriculum also covers advanced topics like probabilistic and randomized complexity. Upon completion, learners will be adept at synthesizing rigorous proofs for resource bounds and applying principles of NP-Completeness to manage computational intractability in problem design.

Course Title: Open Quantum systems and Quantum Thermodynamics
Course Description: This course explores the fundamental kinematics and dynamics of open quantum systems. Beginning with a review of quantum mechanics, it progresses through pure and mixed states, measurement theory, and the intricacies of non-unitary evolution, including completely positive trace preserving maps and entanglement characterization. The syllabus details general quantum dynamical equations, such as the Lindblad equation, and introduces concepts of Markovianity. Finally, it delves into the basics of quantum thermodynamics, including quantum heat engines. Students will gain a robust understanding of noisy quantum systems and insights into current research directions, preparing them for advanced studies and research in quantum information science and related fields.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Review on basic linear algebra; Metric space, Dual space, Hilbert space and bra-ket algebra.
2. Review on unitary quantum mechanics; Unitary evolution, state vectors, uncertainty principle, Schroedinger equation etc.
3. Pure and mixed states, basics on measurement theory, projective measurements, positive operator valued measures etc.
4. non-unitary evolution, tensor product space, bi-paretite quantum systems, global evolutions, non-unitary dynamics, completely positive trace preserving maps, operator-sum representation.
5. Monotones under completely positive operations, basics of distance measures and entropic measures.
6. Selected topics on complete positivity, positivity, Choi-Jamiolkowski isomorphism, Stinspring dilation, entanglement detection.
7. General quantum dynamical equations, master equation, Lindblad equation and its derivation from a few different perspectives, properties of Lindblad dynamics.
8. Basic idea on Markovianity and non-Markovianity from quantum mechanical perspectives.
9. Basic ideas on quantum heat engines and a few other selected topics on thermodynamics.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will analyze quantum systems, identifying pure and mixed states, given a set of measurement outcomes with 80% accuracy
CO2: Students will develop completely positive trace preserving maps for non-unitary evolution, using the operator-sum representation, with a 90% success rate
CO3: Students will apply the Lindblad equation to model open quantum systems, deriving the equation from different perspectives, in a lab setting
CO4: Students will evaluate the Markovianity of a quantum system, using the concept of divisibility, with a 95% confidence level
CO5: Students will design a quantum heat engine, optimizing its efficiency, given a set of thermal resources, with a 10% improvement over existing designs
CO6: Students will construct entanglement detection protocols, using Choi-Jamiolkowski isomorphism, in a noisy quantum system, with a 92% detection rate
CO7: Students will create a research proposal, exploring current research directions in quantum information science, with a clear hypothesis and methodology

Course Description: This course delves into the fundamental principles of probability theory and random processes. Course Description: This course provides a rigorous foundation in probability theory and statistical inference. It commences with discrete and continuous random variables, exploring their distributions, key properties, and moment generating functions. The curriculum progresses to multivariate distributions, covering marginals, conditionals, independence, and the Central Limit Theorem. The course then integrates statistical inference methods (estimation, hypothesis testing, Bayesian approaches) and introduces fundamental random processes. Students will develop the analytical skills to model and interpret probabilistic phenomena, apply statistical inference techniques, and logically derive theoretical results.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Discrete Random Variables: Probability mass function, expectation and variance. Bernoulli distribution, Geometric distribution, Binomial distribution. Derivation of mean and variance. Sampling with and without replacement. Hypergeometric distribution and Poisson distribution. Derivation of the Poisson distribution as limiting form of Binomial. Derivation of mean and variance. Bounding probabilities, tail sum formula, Markov’s inequality and Chebyshev’s inequality. Probability generating functions and moment generating functions.

Unit 2: Continuous Random Variable: Probability density function, cumulative distribution function, expectation, mean and variance. Moment generating functions and uniqueness theorem. Chebyshev’s inequality. The uniform distribution on (a, b), the normal distribution. Mean and variance of the normal distribution. The Cauchy distribution. The exponential distribution, moments, memoryless property, hazard function. Gamma distribution, moments, Chi-square distribution.

Unit 3: Multivariate Distributions: Cumulative distribution function method for finding the distribution of a function of random variable. The transformation rules. Discrete bivariate distributions, marginal and conditional distributions, the trinomial distribution and multinomial distribution. Continuous bivariate distributions, marginal and conditional distributions, independence of random variables. Covariance and correlation. Mean and variance of linear combination of two random variables. The joint Moment generating function (MGF) and MGF of the sum. The bivariate normal distribution, marginal and conditional distributions, conditional expectation and variance, joint MGF and marginal MGF. Linear combinations of independent random variables. Means and variances. Sequences of independent random variables and the weak law of large numbers. The central limit theorem, normal approximation to the binomial distribution.

Unit 4: Statistical Inference and Random Processes: Point Estimation, Interval Estimation, Hypothesis Testing, Linear Regression, Bayesian Inference. Point Processes, Poisson Process, Discrete Time Markov Chains.

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous introduction to Quantum Information Theory, exploring its fundamental principles and applications for information processing. It covers the mathematical postulates of quantum theory, detailing quantum states, channels, and measurements for both closed and open systems. Students will examine various quantum correlations, including entanglement and non-locality, alongside essential mathematical tools such as trace-distance and quantum entropies. The curriculum culminates in an analysis of quantum communication protocols. Upon completion, students will be equipped to analyze information-theoretic aspects of quantum systems and apply these concepts to advanced information processing tasks.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Overview of why the need of quantum information theory: In this part, we will overview the need for quantum information theory. Outline briefly what Shannon information theory means and why and how can we study information theoretical aspects of physical systems obeying quantum theory.

Unit 2: Mathematical formulations of the postulates of the quantum theory: In this part, we will study the postulates of quantum theory pertaining to quantum information theory. We will mainly describe postulates in the form of mathematical statements and rules. We will deal with both closed (unitary evolution) and open (noisy evolution) quantum systems. We will discuss standard theorem statements (e.g., Choi-Jamiołkowski isomorphism) after introducing quantum states, quantum channels, and quantum measurements.

Unit 3: Quantum correlations: In this part, we will discuss different kinds of quantum correlations. We will mainly focus on quantum correlations like entanglement and nonlocal quantum correlations. We will discuss measures and tests to quantify or test these correlations. We may touch upon local hidden variable theories to derive Bell tests for nonlocal quantum correlations.

Unit 4: Tools in quantum information theory: In this part, we will introduce and discuss some of the important tools that are employed widely in the domain of quantum information theory. Some of these tools are trace-distance, relative entropy, fidelity, etc. We will discuss formula and bounds for quantum entropy, quantum conditional entropy, quantum mutual information, quantum conditional mutual information. We will discuss quantum data-processing inequality, strong subadditivity, and other entropic measures and inequalities.

Unit 5: Quantum communication protocol: In this part, we will discuss quantum typicality, packing lemma, covering lemma, and some examples of quantum communication protocols. We may touch upon quantum resource theories and their frameworks if time permits.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will analyze the principles of quantum information theory, including quantum states, channels, and measurements, in both closed and open systems with mathematical rigor and accuracy
CO2: Students will develop mathematical formulations of the postulates of quantum theory, including the Choi-Jamiołkowski isomorphism, using standard theorem statements
CO3: Students will evaluate quantum correlations, including entanglement and non-locality, by applying measures and tests to quantify and test these correlations with 80% accuracy
CO4: Students will apply essential mathematical tools, such as trace-distance and quantum entropies, to analyze information-theoretic aspects of quantum systems efficiently
CO5: Students will design a quantum communication protocol, including quantum typicality and packing lemma, to achieve reliable information transmission with 90% fidelity
CO6: Students will implement quantum information processing tasks, such as quantum data-processing inequality and strong subadditivity, using Python programming language

Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles and advanced methodologies of signal detection and estimation theory. It rigorously covers optimal estimation techniques, including Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) estimation, Cramer-Rao bound, and practical estimators like Maximum Likelihood (MLE), Least Squares (LSE), and Bayesian approaches. Concurrently, it investigates hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson criterion, and likelihood ratio tests for optimal signal detection under diverse conditions, ranging from deterministic to random signals with known or unknown parameters. Students will develop analytical and design skills to implement optimal detectors and estimators, applying these robust techniques to complex problems across engineering disciplines.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Estimation Theory - Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) Estimation, Cramer Rao lower bound, Fisher Information, Neyman-Fisher factorization, Sufficient and complete test statistics, Rao Blackwell-Lehmann-Scheffe theorem.

Unit 2: Estimation methods - Best linear unbiased estimation (BLUE), Least square estimation (LSE), Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), Bayesian Approach, Numerical methods - Newton Raphson and Expectation maximization (EM) methods.

Unit 3: Detection Theory - Hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson (NP) theorem, Likelihood ratio test (LRT), Receiver operating characteristic (ROC), Minimum probability of error, Bayes Risk, Minimum Bayes risk detector, MAP detector.

Unit 4: Detection methods–Detection of deterministic signals - Matched filter for WGN and non WGN, Binary and M-array signal detection using matched filter. Detection of random signals - Estimator-correlator and linear model; Detection of deterministic signal with unknown parameters - Composite hypothesis testing, Generalized LRT (GLRT), Bayesian approach, Rao test, Wald test.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles governing the interaction of matter with electromagnetic radiation across various energy regimes. It systematically covers atomic and molecular spectra, applying both classical and quantum mechanical models to explain electronic, vibrational, and rotational transitions. Detailed discussions include Raman, Infrared, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopies. Students will develop the analytical skills to interpret complex spectra, apply theoretical models to spectroscopic phenomena, and calculate molecular properties derived from experimental data.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: Classical mechanical description of spectroscopy, quantum mechanics and energy quantization, energy-level diagram, energy spectrum: electronic states, vibrational states, rotational states, excitation and relaxation, absorption and emission of electromagnetic waves by materials
Unit 2: Atomic Spectra: Spectral series of hydrogen and alkali atoms, selection rules, L-S coupling, many-electron atoms, isotope shift, hyperfine splitting of spectral lines

Unit 3: Molecular Spectra: Electronic spectra of diatomic and polyatomic molecules, Born- Oppenheimer approximation, Franck-Condon principle, absorption and emission spectra, fluorescence and phosphorescence, Jablonsky diagram, effect of solvation of electronic spectra, rotational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using a rigid rotator model, energy levels and spectrum of a non-rigid diatomic molecule, effect of isotopic substitution on rotational spectra, vibrational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using the harmonic and anharmonic oscillator models. vibrational- rotational coupling in a diatomic molecule, molecular spectra of chain molecules

Unit 4: Raman and Infrared Spectroscopy: Classical and quantum theory of Raman effect, normal vibrations of CO2 and H2O molecules, vibrational and rotational Raman spectra, basic concept of infrared spectroscopy, interpretation of Raman and IR spectra, identification of Raman-active and/or IR-active modes based on symmetry arguments
Unit 5: Introduction to Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopy

Course Description: This course provides the knowledge and skills to mathematically model and analyze the dynamic response of structural systems. It covers the formulation of equations of motion for Single- and Multi-Degree of Freedom (SDOF, MDOF) systems, exploring free and forced vibrations, damping, and mode superposition. The curriculum details numerical and approximate methods for computing natural frequencies, including Eigenvalue problems, Ritz vectors, and direct integration techniques. A major focus is on base-excited systems, response spectrum concepts, and their application in earthquake engineering, referencing codes like IS 1893. Students will be able to employ computational tools to predict and improve structural response to dynamic loading.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Response of simple Single Degree of Freedom (SDOF) systems Introduction to structural dynamics; Definition of DOF; idealization of structure as SDOF system; Formulation of equations of motion for various SDOF systems; Free vibration of systems; Damping in structures; Undamped Systems; Forced vibration of systems; Steady state response to harmonic forces; Experimental determinations of natural frequency; Duhamel's integral and other methods.

Unit 2: Analysis of Multi-Degree of Freedom (MDOF) systems Static force displacement relationship; Strain energy of system; Formulation of equation of motion; Evaluation of natural frequencies and modes; Free vibration of undamped systems; Forced vibration of damped systems; Review of time history & response spectrum methods.

Unit 3: Numerical Methods, and Approximate methods of computing natural frequencies Eigen value problems and applications: Mode superposition principle; modal truncation errors; Ritz Vector approach; Direct Integration methods: Explicit methods - Central difference method; Implicit methods - Newmark-ß method; Rayleigh's method; Dunkerley's method; Rayleigh-Ritz method

Unit 4: Base excited systems Formulation of equations of motion for SDOF and MDOF systems; Concept of spectral quantities; Response spectrum; Fundamentals of earthquake engineering; Discussion onIS 1893 (1:2016 provisions for buildings.
Unit 5: Overview of dynamics of continuous systems Vibration of flexural beams and shear beams: Equation of motion; Free vibration and Forced vibration

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of the Theory of Elasticity, distinguishing it from Strength of Materials and emphasizing mathematical rigor. It begins with the fundamental concepts of stress, strain, traction, and the necessary mathematical preliminaries, including tensor and matrix representation. The core of the course establishes the governing equations of elasticity: generalized Hook’s law, equilibrium equations, strain-displacement relations, and compatibility conditions. It then applies these principles to formulate and solve 2D boundary value problems using stress functions and the biharmonic equation, specifically for plane stress and plane strain states. The course concludes with an analysis of torsion, bending, and elastic stability, enabling students to idealize physical systems and derive solutions for complex problems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Elasticity and its types, Inelastic material, Difference between theory of elasticity and strength of material, Materials and its properties, Assumptions in elasticity, Mathematical preliminaries: cartesian co-ordinates, introduction to tensor, matrix representation, operators and symbols.

Unit 2: Concept of stresses and strains, Infinitesimal area and volume, 2D and 3D stress tensor, Stress and strain transformation at a point in an elastic body, Difference between stress and traction, Cauchy’s stress, Components of traction, Strain tensors, Types of deformation, Measurement of surface strains

Unit 3: Rigid body translation and rotation of an element in space, Generalized Hook’s law, Stress- strain relationships, Equilibrium equations, Strain-displacement relationships, Compatibility conditions, Constitutive relations.

Unit 4: Principal planes, Principal stresses and invariants, Octahedral plane and stresses, Deviatoric stress, Hydrostatic stress, Plain stress, Plain strain, Formulation of boundary value problems in equilibrium and compatibility, Stress functions, Biharmonic equation, Solution of 2D problems by the use of polynomials.

Unit 5: Torsion of bars, Saint venant principle, Rigid body rotation, bending of beams, Elastic stability, Factors affecting lateral stability, Analysis of beam-column with different loading conditions, Different types of buckling.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will apply the fundamental concepts of stress, strain, and traction to idealize physical systems and derive solutions for complex problems using tensor and matrix representation with 80% accuracy.

CO2: Students will analyze 2D boundary value problems using stress functions and the biharmonic equation to solve for plane stress and plane strain states given Cartesian coordinates and mathematical preliminaries.

CO3: Students will develop the governing equations of elasticity, including generalized Hook's law, equilibrium equations, strain-displacement relations, and compatibility conditions, using mathematical derivations with 90% accuracy.

CO4: Students will implement the principles of torsion, bending, and elastic stability to formulate and solve problems involving bars, beams, and columns with different loading conditions using Saint Venant's principle and rigid body rotation.

CO5: Students will evaluate the differences between the Theory of Elasticity and Strength of Materials, identifying key assumptions and limitations, and justify the choice of approach for a given problem scenario with 85% accuracy.
CO6: Students will construct 2D and 3D stress tensors, and perform stress and strain transformations at a point in an elastic body, using Cauchy's stress and strain tensors with 95% accuracy.

CO7: Students will create a mathematical model of an elastic system, incorporating constitutive relations, compatibility conditions, and equilibrium equations, to predict the behavior of the system under various loading conditions with 80% accuracy.

Course Title: Thinking and Knowing in the Human Sciences – II
Course Description: This course explores methods of thinking and knowing about society through the lenses of history and sociology. It introduces fundamental sociological concepts such as social structures, culture, and deviance, followed by an in-depth study of major theoretical frameworks for understanding social stratification, including Structural Functionalist, Marxist, and Weberian approaches. The course also examines social institutions and processes specific to India. On the historical side, it analyzes different ideas of history (Progress, Decline) and the main methods of knowing the past, such as structuralism and post-structuralism, alongside concepts of time and space. Students will gain experience in using sociological and historiographical theories to critically engage with and analyze complex social phenomena.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Sociological Concepts: Social Structures, Individuals and Groups, Socialisation, Structure/Agency, Status and Roles, Rules, Values, Norms, Culture, Discourse, Deviance.

Unit 2: Sociological Frameworks and Theories: Understanding social stratification through the structural functionalist, Marxist and the Weberian methods. Introduction to key ideas of Emile Durkheim, Karl Marx and Max Weber.
Unit 3: Social Institutions and Processes in India.
Unit 4: Ideas of History (Progress, Decline, Morality; Facts, Objectivity, Interpretation)
Unit 5: Concepts of Time and Space
Unit 6: Main methods of knowing the past (Inductive and deductive methods; structuralism and post-structuralism).

Course Description: This course focuses on the theory and application of optimization techniques essential for modern data science. It begins by establishing a rigorous foundation in convex analysis, covering convex sets, functions, duality, and the formulation of convex optimization problems. The core of the curriculum is dedicated to exploring and analyzing various optimization solvers, including classical methods like Steepest Descent and Newton methods, as well as modern stochastic algorithms like SGD, RMSprop, and ADAM, with a focus on convergence estimates and complexity analysis. The course concludes by demonstrating the practical application of these methods in key data science areas such as Support Vector Machines, Neural Networks, Recommender Systems, and GANs. Students will be equipped to model applications as optimization problems, code efficient solvers, and apply them in research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Convex Sets, Convex Functions, Duality, Convex Optimization Problems (9 hours)
Unit 2: Steepest Descent, Newton methods, Quasi-Newton Methods, Interior Point Methods, Stochastic Optimization algorithms (SGD, RMSprop, ADAM, SVRG, etc.), Convergence Estimates (6 hours)

Unit 3: Applications of optimization: Recommender Systems, Support Vector Machines, Neural networks, Image, and Video Completion, Extreme Classification, Gans (9 hours) - A project related to the above syllabus will be done by students.

Course Description: This course explores the interdisciplinary field of Nanoscience, focusing on the unique properties, synthesis, and applications of nanomaterials. The curriculum establishes foundational concepts, including length scales, surface energy, and the classification of nanomaterials (clusters, nanoparticles). A core focus is on how nanoscale confinement effects lead to distinct electrical, optical, magnetic, and thermal properties. The course covers both top-down and bottom-up synthesis methods and introduces the essential tools for nano-system characterization, such as AFM, SEM, and TEM. Emphasis is placed on real-world applications in catalysis, sensing, quantum devices, and theragnostics, concluding with a critical discussion on the environmental and health hazards of nanotechnology. Students will analyze size- and shape-dependent properties and identify suitable experimental techniques for nanoscale research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1. Introduction to Nanoscience. (3L) Nanomaterials: Definitions and Scopes. Length Scales: Size Scales, Surface and Interface, Surface Energy, Coordination Numbers. Classification of nanomaterials: Clusters and Magic Numbers, Nanoparticles, and Colloids. Metal, Semiconductor, and Bio Nanomaterials.

Unit 2. Properties of Nanomaterials. (9L) Electrons in Nanostructures. Discrete states vs. band structure: Effects of dimensionality and symmetry in nanostructures. Metal-to-nonmetal transition. Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Small-Sized Systems. Capillarity, Liquid droplets, Lotus effect. Self- assembly principles. Adsorption, Electrostatic and Steric Stabilization. Classical nucleation theory. Size and shape control in nanoparticle formation. Magnetic (Super paramagnetism), Electrical (quantized conduction and Coulomb Staircase), Optical (size and shape effects), Thermal (melting and conduction), Mechanical and Catalytic properties.
Unit 3. Making Nanostructures. (3L) Top-down and bottom-up methods.
Unit 4. Tools for Nano systems. Microstructure/Chemistry/Defects and Structure. (5L) AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, SAXS, Nanoindentation.

Unit 5. Applications of Nanomaterials. (4L) Catalysis, Band Gap Engineered Quantum Devices, Sensors, Field Effect Transistor (FET), Photoelectrochemical Cells, Photonic Crystals and Waveguides, Theragnostics (Magnetothermal Therapy), food and agriculture industries, automobile, textile, water treatment and civil applications, use in energy, space, and defense.
Unit 6. Concerns and Challenges of Nanotechnology. (2L) Environmental, ecological and health hazards of nanoparticles. Nanotoxicology and its effect.

CO2: Students will analyze the effects of dimensionality and symmetry on the electrical, optical, magnetic, and thermal properties of nanomaterials using quantum mechanics and statistical thermodynamics principles
CO3: Students will design and propose a synthesis method for a given nanomaterial using either top-down or bottom-up approaches with justification of the chosen method

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive study of Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Design, focusing on CMOS technology and circuit optimization. It begins with an introduction to the VLSI design flow, MOSFET/FinFET transistors, and the detailed analysis of the CMOS inverter's static and dynamic characteristics (delay, power, noise margin). The core curriculum extends these principles to the design of fundamental digital building blocks like gates, latches, and flip-flops. A major emphasis is placed on delay optimization for multistage logic circuits using the Method of Logical Effort, and exploring alternative logic styles such as Pass Transistor and Dynamic Logic. Concluding with an introduction to system design using HDL, students will gain the skills to analyze, design, and verify delay-optimized combinational and sequential CMOS circuits.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1 (Introduction to VLSI design):1) Introduction to VLSI design (top-bottom approach) - flow, applications, technologies, 2) MOSFET, FinFET transistors – Geometry and model, 3) Introduction to basic building blocks - SPICE, HDL, layout, 4) Moore’s law, technology scaling, current trends(5- lectures/7.5-hours)

Unit 2 (CMOS Inverter): 1) Static characteristics- VTC, switching threshold, Noise margin, 2) Dynamic characteristics – rise time, fall time, delay, power, 3) Why CMOS Inverter, 4) CMOS inverter design flow- problem of achieving higher speeds (solution/technique discussed in the following unit), 5) From inverters to other logic - pull-up, pull-down networks, tristate inverter, Gates, Mux, Latches, Flip-flops, set-up hold time, clocked CMOS and true single phase clocked (TSPC) latches (7- lectures/10.5-hours)

Unit 3 (Multistage Logic Design and Optimization: 1) Parasitics in layout causing performance degradation – field transistor, active MOS, gate-drain overlap, latch-up, 2) Method of logical effort- fan-out, Stage effort, electrical effort, device sizing, design examples. (5-lectures/7.5-hours)
Unit 4 (Other Logic Styles): Pseudo nMOS, pass transistor logic, Cascode Voltage Switch Logic (CVSL), Dynamic logic. (3-lecturs/4.5-hours)

Unit 5 (Other topics Introduction to System Design using HDL): Finite state machines – Mealy, Moore, Intro to RTL,Data path, Control unit, combinational and sequential circuit design examples (6-lectures/9-hours)
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will design and analyze CMOS inverters using SPICE and HDL tools with 90% accuracy in static and dynamic characteristics
CO2: Students will develop and optimize multistage logic circuits using the Method of Logical Effort with a 20% reduction in delay
CO3: Students will implement and verify delay-optimized combinational and sequential CMOS circuits using HDL and SPICE with 95% accuracy
CO4: Students will evaluate and compare the performance of alternative logic styles such as Pass Transistor and Dynamic Logic in terms of power consumption and delay
CO5: Students will create and simulate digital system designs using HDL and verify their functionality with 100% accuracy
CO6: Students will apply Moore's law and technology scaling principles to predict future trends in VLSI design with 80% accuracy
CO7: Students will construct and analyze a finite state machine using Mealy and Moore models with 90% accuracy

Course Title: Work, Entrepreneurship and Technology in Contemporary Societies.
Course Description: This course offers a critical sociological examination of the interconnected spheres of work, entrepreneurship, and technology in contemporary societies. It begins by exploring the foundational theories and historical discourses of work, covering diverse forms, including formal, informal, productive, and reproductive labor, and analyzing the influence of social institutions like gender and caste. The curriculum then introduces the concept of entrepreneurship, investigating different types, from Silicon Valley to self-employed enterprises, and the role of finance, capital, and social networks in these processes. A final module focuses on the historical transformation of technology and its role as an institution that shapes work relations and contingent labor. Students will develop a critical outlook to analyze how technology drives and is adopted within these deeply connected economic engagements.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1 Sociology of work: - Theories and basic concepts of work. - Historical discourses and practices around work. - Introduction to sectoral (agriculture, manufacturing, and service) understanding of work in contemporary markets.

Unit-2 Diverse forms of work: Formal and informal work, and productive and reproductive work. Debt and bondage in labour markets; precarity and dignity within contemporary work arrangements. Role of social institutions (gender, caste, and technology) in shaping work and work relations.

Unit-3 Introduction to entrepreneurship: Definition of entrepreneurship, historical discourses in the sociology of entrepreneurship: charismatic individuals, entrepreneurial groups, entrepreneurship as a process. Types of entrepreneurial engagements: Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, intrapreneurship, main-street entrepreneurs, and self-employed entrepreneurs.

Unit-4 Entrepreneurial processes and outcomes: Value creation and the role of finance in entrepreneurship. Role of social networks (kinship and peer networks) in the entrepreneurial process. Reciprocity and resources within entrepreneurial ventures.

Unit-5 Technology and contemporary economy: Historical transformation technology from the 19th century to the present – highlighting key phases of technological transformation, Globalization and technological adoption, Contingent work and digital technology, Role of technology in contemporary entrepreneurship, and technology as an institution.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Students will analyze the historical discourses of work using foundational sociological theories given primary sources with 80% accuracy
CO2: Students will evaluate the impact of social institutions on work relations and contingent labor using case studies in a group setting with peer feedback

CO3: Students will develop a critical perspective on entrepreneurship by comparing different types of entrepreneurial engagements, including Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and self-employed entrepreneurs, in a written reflection with clear examples
CO4: Students will design a value creation process for an entrepreneurial venture using finance and social network concepts with a clear business model
CO5: Students will apply the concept of technological transformation to contemporary economic arrangements, including globalization and contingent work, in a multimedia presentation with visual aids

CO6: Students will construct an argument about the role of technology as an institution in shaping work relations and entrepreneurial processes using evidence from historical and contemporary examples with logical reasoning
CO7: Students will create a scenario for a future of work that integrates insights from sociology, entrepreneurship, and technology studies in a written report with clear recommendations

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental operational and design problems of modern Wireless Communications systems. It begins with a review of digital communication basics and an overview of current wireless standards and generations. The core curriculum delves into channel modeling, focusing on multipath propagation, pathloss, and various types of fading (frequency and time selectivity). It then progresses to essential mitigation techniques, covering the design and performance analysis of spatial, time, and frequency diversity techniques. The course concludes with advanced topics, including Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) communication systems, capacity analysis, and a detailed examination of Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing (OFDM) and Massive MIMO, preparing students to design and evaluate rate and error performance of multi-antenna transceivers.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Review of digital communication, optimal detection, overview of wireless communication generations and standards
Unit 2: Channel modeling; Multipath propagation; pathloss and fading; types of fading; frequency and time selectivity
Unit 3: Diversity techniques; spatial, time and frequency diversity; performance analysis of various diversity techniques
Unit 4: MIMO communication systems; capacity analysis; MIMO receivers
Unit 5: OFDM, massive MIMO, multiuser communication

CO4: Students will evaluate the performance of MIMO communication systems using simulation tools with a mean squared error of less than 0.1
